questions.text: When identifying errors in a Gantt chart, circling part of the error is sufficient to show you found it.
questions.explanation: You must circle the whole error, not just part of it. Partial circles suggest incomplete understanding. Make your identification clear and complete.
questions.studyTip: Circle the ENTIRE error—don't leave assessors guessing

questions.text: When marking errors on diagrams, you should clearly indicate the complete extent of each error.
questions.explanation: Complete, clear marking shows you understand exactly what's wrong. Partial or unclear marking loses marks even if you've spotted the issue.
questions.studyTip: Be precise—show exactly what and where the error is

questions.text: When asked to justify a choice, explaining why your option is good is enough for full marks.
questions.explanation: Justification requires comparison. You must explain why your chosen option is better AND why the alternatives are less suitable. Just saying yours is good isn't justification.
questions.studyTip: Justify = why this one is better + why others are worse

questions.text: A complete justification compares the chosen option against alternatives and explains why it's preferred.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses state: 'Design A is appropriate because [reason]. Design B is not appropriate because [reason].' Cover both sides.
questions.studyTip: Always address why the rejected options don't work

questions.text: When citing the Privacy Act, just naming the act is enough—the year is optional detail.
questions.explanation: You must include the correct year to receive marks. 'Privacy Act 1988' gets the mark; 'Privacy Act' alone does not. The year is part of the official title.
questions.studyTip: Privacy Act 1988. Always include the year.

questions.text: Legislation references must include the correct year to be awarded marks.
questions.explanation: Acts are identified by name AND year. Privacy Act 1988, Privacy and Data Protection Act 2014, Copyright Act 1968—learn the years as part of the name.
questions.studyTip: Memorise: Privacy Act 1988, Copyright Act 1968

questions.text: Generic examples from your own knowledge are just as good as examples from the case study.
questions.explanation: Examiners explicitly state you must give examples that relate to the case study to gain full marks. Generic examples show you haven't engaged with the scenario.
questions.studyTip: Use names, data, and specifics from the case study

questions.text: Examples must relate directly to the given case study or question scenario to earn full marks.
questions.explanation: If the case study involves wheat production data, your validation example should reference wheat yields, not generic 'numbers'. Context-specific answers score higher.
questions.studyTip: Read the case study. Use its details in your answers.

questions.text: The exam only tests what's covered in class, so you don't need to read the official study design.
questions.explanation: Examiners state students should be familiar with the Applied Computing Study Design and 'Software tools and functions' document from the beginning of each year. These define examinable content.
questions.studyTip: Read the study design and software tools document early

questions.text: Familiarity with the official study design and software tools document is essential for exam preparation.
questions.explanation: These documents define exactly what can be examined. Questions on research questions, design tools, and effectiveness directly reference study design terminology.
questions.studyTip: The study design IS the syllabus. Know it.

questions.text: Evaluation criteria like 'the system should be fast' are acceptable if they describe what you want.
questions.explanation: Criteria must be measurable. 'Fast' isn't measurable. 'Loads within 3 seconds' is. Vague criteria cannot be objectively evaluated.
questions.studyTip: Can you measure it with a number? If not, rewrite it.

questions.text: Evaluation criteria must be measurable and specific enough to objectively assess.
questions.explanation: Good criteria: 'How many data breaches occurred?' Bad criteria: 'Is it secure?' The first can be counted; the second is subjective.
questions.studyTip: Measurable = numbers, counts, specific outcomes

questions.text: With weekly differential backups on Friday night, maximum data loss if disaster strikes is one day.
questions.explanation: Maximum loss is seven days. If disaster occurs Friday night just before backup, you lose the entire week's changes since the last backup. Think worst-case timing.
questions.studyTip: Backup frequency × worst timing = maximum data loss

questions.text: Maximum data loss equals the time since the last successful backup in a worst-case scenario.
questions.explanation: Weekly backup = up to 7 days loss. Daily backup = up to 1 day loss. Calculate based on backup frequency and worst possible timing of a disaster.
questions.studyTip: Always calculate the worst case, not the average

questions.text: Incremental and differential backups are the same thing—both copy changes since the last backup.
questions.explanation: They're different. Incremental copies changes since the last backup (of any type). Differential copies ALL changes since the last FULL backup. Differential files grow larger over time.
questions.studyTip: Incremental: since last backup. Differential: since last FULL.

questions.text: Differential backups copy all changes since the last full backup, growing larger over time.
questions.explanation: Monday's differential has 1 day of changes. Thursday's has 4 days of changes—all since Friday's full backup. Incremental backups stay small but need more files to restore.
questions.studyTip: Differential grows. Incremental stays small but needs chain.

questions.text: Range checks validate that data falls within acceptable minimum and maximum values.
questions.explanation: Range check example: Year >= 2018 AND Year <= 2022. This ensures data stays within project-relevant bounds. Always specify both the rule AND a case-study-specific example.
questions.studyTip: Range check = min/max boundaries for valid values

questions.text: A data type check ensures values fall within an acceptable range of numbers.
questions.explanation: Data type check ensures the right kind of data (numeric, text, date)—not the range. Range check handles acceptable values. Don't confuse these validation types.
questions.studyTip: Type check: is it a number? Range check: is it the RIGHT number?

questions.text: Dependency lines can start from anywhere on a task bar as long as they connect to the next task.
questions.explanation: Dependencies must start at the END of the predecessor task and connect to the START of the dependent task. Lines starting or ending mid-task lose marks.
questions.studyTip: End of Task A → Start of Task B. No mid-task connections.

questions.text: Gantt chart dependencies run from the end of one task through milestones to the start of the next task.
questions.explanation: The line must: (1) start at the task's end, (2) pass through any milestone on the line, (3) arrive at the next task's start. All three elements matter.
questions.studyTip: Task end → through milestone → task start

questions.text: Milestones can be placed anywhere within the day they relate to on a Gantt chart.
questions.explanation: Milestones must be on the line—specifically at the START of the day the milestone relates to. Floating milestones in the middle of a cell lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Milestone = on the line, start of the relevant day

questions.text: Milestones in Gantt charts should be positioned on the gridline at the start of their relevant day.
questions.explanation: Milestones mark completion points. They sit on the boundary line, showing exactly when a phase ends. This precision matters for accurate project tracking.
questions.studyTip: Milestones sit ON the line, not floating in space

questions.text: Adding a title to a graph is the most important convention for helping users interpret it accurately.
questions.explanation: Titles alone don't help accurate interpretation. Axis labels, scales, legends, and consistent intervals do. Students who only mentioned titles weren't awarded marks.
questions.studyTip: Conventions for accuracy: axes, scales, legends, intervals

questions.text: Graph conventions like labelled axes, clear scales, and legends help users accurately interpret data.
questions.explanation: Essential conventions: label both axes, show measurement units, use regular intervals, include a legend for multiple series, add tooltips for interactive elements.
questions.studyTip: Label axes. Show units. Add legend. Clear scale.

questions.text: Data integrity only means the data hasn't been deliberately tampered with.
questions.explanation: Integrity covers accuracy, correctness, reasonableness, and completeness. Negative snow depths, inconsistent units (m vs cm), typos ('Spencers ©reek'), and duplicates all lack integrity.
questions.studyTip: Integrity = accurate + correct + reasonable + complete

questions.text: Data lacking integrity includes values outside valid ranges, inconsistent formats, and duplicate entries.
questions.explanation: Identify integrity issues by checking: Is the value possible? (reasonableness) Is it spelled correctly? (correctness) Are units consistent? (accuracy) Are there duplicates?
questions.studyTip: Check: possible? correct? consistent? unique?

questions.text: Design principles like contrast and balance relate to functionality, not appearance.
questions.explanation: Contrast, balance, alignment, space, and image use are APPEARANCE principles. Ease of use is the FUNCTIONALITY principle. Students frequently misclassify these.
questions.studyTip: Appearance: contrast, balance, alignment, space, images. Functionality: ease of use.

questions.text: Ease of use is the design principle that relates to functionality; contrast and balance relate to appearance.
questions.explanation: This distinction is critical. Functionality = how easy to use. Appearance = how it looks. Know which principles fall into each category.
questions.studyTip: Functionality = usability. Appearance = visual design.

questions.text: Error tolerance means the visualisation can function despite having errors in the data.
questions.explanation: This is a common misconception that lost marks. Error tolerance is about handling USER mistakes—providing helpful error messages, undo options, and preventing invalid inputs.
questions.studyTip: Error tolerance = handles USER errors, not data errors

questions.text: Error tolerance refers to how a system handles user mistakes through warnings, undo options, and prevention.
questions.explanation: Examples: displaying warning messages instead of crashing, showing tooltips, greying out invalid options, allowing undo. It's about gracefully managing user errors.
questions.studyTip: Error tolerance: warnings, undo, prevention—not data errors

questions.text: A Geographic Information System (GIS) is just another name for an online map like Google Maps.
questions.explanation: GIS is a system for capturing, storing, analysing, and displaying geographic data. It combines location data with other information for analysis and visualisation—more than just showing maps.
questions.studyTip: GIS = geographic data + analysis + visualisation

questions.text: GIS combines geographic location data with other information to enable spatial analysis and visualisation.
questions.explanation: GIS lets you layer different data types onto geographic locations—population, rainfall, crop yields—and analyse spatial relationships. Know how this applies to data visualisation.
questions.studyTip: GIS: where + what, layered for analysis

questions.text: Chart type (bar, line, pie) and axis labels are both examples of data visualisation conventions.
questions.explanation: Chart type is a FORMAT—the structure you choose. Conventions are standards applied to any format: axis titles, legends, scales, consistent intervals. Don't confuse them.
questions.studyTip: Format = chart type. Convention = labels, legends, scales.

questions.text: Formats are the chart types chosen; conventions are the standards applied like axis labels and legends.
questions.explanation: Line chart = format. Labelled axes, legend, title = conventions. You choose a format, then apply conventions to make it effective.
questions.studyTip: Pick a format, then apply conventions to it

questions.text: Any question about the project topic qualifies as a valid research question.
questions.explanation: Research questions must start with 'What', 'Why', or 'How'. 'Is the data accurate?' is not valid. 'What factors affect data accuracy?' is valid. Structure matters.
questions.studyTip: Research questions: What/Why/How + open-ended

questions.text: Valid research questions begin with 'What', 'Why', or 'How' and invite investigation.
questions.explanation: These starters create open-ended questions that require analysis and investigation. Yes/no questions don't qualify. Check your question starters.
questions.studyTip: What/Why/How = research question. Is/Does/Can = not.

questions.text: Data and information mean the same thing and can be used interchangeably.
questions.explanation: Data is raw, isolated facts. Information is processed, contextualised data that's useful for decision-making. The distinction matters in exam responses.
questions.studyTip: Data = raw facts. Information = processed, useful data.

questions.text: Data becomes information when it is processed and given context that makes it useful.
questions.explanation: Sales figures are data. 'Sales increased 15% after the campaign' is information. Organisations need both: data to store, information to decide.
questions.studyTip: Process data → get information → make decisions

questions.text: Describing shredding as 'using a shredder on documents' is a complete explanation.
questions.explanation: This just restates the word. You must explain that shredding destroys or cuts documents into unrecognisable pieces so information cannot be recovered. Explain the outcome.
questions.studyTip: Shredding = destroying into unrecognisable pieces

questions.text: Shredding means destroying documents by cutting them into pieces so information cannot be recovered.
questions.explanation: The key is 'unrecognisable' and 'cannot be recovered'. This explains WHY shredding works as a security measure, not just what the machine does.
questions.studyTip: Explain the security outcome, not just the action

concepts.title: Apply validation to the case study

questions.text: A generic validation example like 'check the data is correct' demonstrates understanding.
questions.explanation: Generic examples don't earn full marks. If validating rainfall data, write: 'Range check: Rainfall >= 0 AND Rainfall <= 500mm to ensure values are within possible range for the region.'
questions.studyTip: Validation example MUST use case study specifics

questions.text: Validation examples should reference specific fields and values from the case study scenario.
questions.explanation: Instead of 'check year is valid', write 'Range check: Year >= 2018 AND Year <= 2022 to ensure data falls within the project's five-year scope.' Specific beats generic.
questions.studyTip: Name the field. State the rule. Reference the scenario.

questions.text: Stating what you would test is enough to describe a testing technique.
questions.explanation: Complete testing descriptions need three parts: (1) state what you'll test, (2) describe the test data and expected result, (3) explain what to do if it fails. Most students miss step 3.
questions.studyTip: Test what + expected result + what if it fails

questions.text: A complete testing description includes the test, expected result, and action if it fails.
questions.explanation: Example: 'Test numeric-only entry. Enter 22 (should accept) and abc (should show error). If no error for abc, check data type validation is enabled.' All three parts matter.
questions.studyTip: Test → expect → fix if wrong

questions.text: Listing security controls like '2FA' and 'encryption' is sufficient for security questions.
questions.explanation: Almost half of students only stated controls without explaining why they're appropriate. You need both: name the control AND explain how it prevents the specific threat.
questions.studyTip: Name the control + explain HOW it helps

questions.text: Security recommendations must name the control and explain how it addresses the specific threat.
questions.explanation: 'Implement 2FA. This requires two forms of identification, so even if a password is compromised, attackers still cannot access the system.' Control + mechanism + benefit.
questions.studyTip: What is it? How does it work? Why does it help?

questions.text: Normalisation just means organising data into tables—any logical grouping works.
questions.explanation: Third normal form has specific requirements: reasonable table names, all fields correctly placed, primary keys in every table, foreign keys linking tables. Calculated fields don't belong in normalised tables.
questions.studyTip: 3NF: PKs, FKs, no calculated fields, no redundancy

questions.text: Normalised tables require primary keys, foreign keys, and should not contain calculated fields.
questions.explanation: Total Cost doesn't belong in a transaction table—it's calculated from other fields. Each table needs a PK. Related tables link via FKs. Understand these rules.
questions.studyTip: If it's calculated, it shouldn't be stored

questions.text: Any design tool can be used for any design task—they're all equivalent.
questions.explanation: Specific tools match specific tasks: Data dictionary for database fields. IPO charts for spreadsheet formulas. Layout diagrams/mockups for visualisation appearance. Know which matches which.
questions.studyTip: Data dictionary → database. IPO → formulas. Mockups → appearance.

questions.text: Design tools are matched to specific purposes: data dictionaries for databases, IPO charts for formulas.
questions.explanation: Database fields = data dictionary. Spreadsheet formulas = IPO charts. Visualisation appearance = layout diagrams, annotated diagrams, mockups, storyboards. Learn these pairings.
questions.studyTip: Know which tool fits which design task

questions.text: Testing a dynamic visualisation means checking that all the charts display correctly.
questions.explanation: You must test INTERACTIVITY. Click on controls, change values, and verify the visualisation updates correctly. Compare displayed data against source data to confirm accuracy.
questions.studyTip: Click, change, verify—test the dynamic parts

questions.text: Testing dynamic visualisations involves interacting with controls and verifying data updates correctly.
questions.explanation: Click dropdown, change year, check chart updates. Change region filter, verify correct data displays. Compare what shows against what should show. Test the 'dynamic' in 'dynamic visualisation'.
questions.studyTip: Interact with every control. Check every update.

questions.text: Referencing sources is optional if you're confident the information is accurate.
questions.explanation: Referencing is required to: acknowledge authors/intellectual property, demonstrate data authenticity, provide readers with source information, protect against plagiarism claims, comply with Copyright Act 1968.
questions.studyTip: Reference = credit + credibility + copyright compliance

questions.text: Referencing acknowledges intellectual property, demonstrates authenticity, and provides source information.
questions.explanation: Multiple valid reasons exist. Pick whichever fits the question: crediting authors, showing authenticity, enabling readers to verify, avoiding plagiarism, legal compliance.
questions.studyTip: Know multiple reasons—examiners accept various valid answers

questions.text: If data is available online, it's acceptable to use regardless of the source.
questions.explanation: Unknown sources with no author or non-credentialed websites may provide biased or inauthentic data. Using such sources harms data integrity. Evaluate credibility before using.
questions.studyTip: Unknown source = questionable authenticity = don't use

questions.text: Data from unknown or non-credentialed sources should not be used as it may harm integrity.
questions.explanation: Ask: Who created this? Are they qualified? Is the website reputable? If you can't verify the origin, the data could be biased, inaccurate, or fabricated.
questions.studyTip: No author + no credentials = no trust

questions.text: Archiving data means deleting files that are no longer needed for current operations.
questions.explanation: Archiving is NOT deleting. It means moving data to another location (external drive, cloud) to free up space while maintaining access for future reference. Data is preserved, not destroyed.
questions.studyTip: Archive = move + keep accessible. Delete = gone forever.

questions.text: Archiving involves moving data to secondary storage while maintaining the ability to access it when needed.
questions.explanation: Files not needed for daily operations but potentially useful later get archived. Move to external storage, free up primary space, but ensure you can retrieve them if needed.
questions.studyTip: Archive: not using now, might need later, keep accessible

questions.text: AI risks include general technology concerns like system crashes and hardware failures.
questions.explanation: AI-specific risks are: privacy of training data, bias in training data reinforcing discrimination, and lack of transparency in decision-making. Generic tech risks don't answer AI risk questions.
questions.studyTip: AI risks: privacy, bias, transparency—not generic tech issues

questions.text: AI risks include privacy concerns with training data, algorithmic bias, and lack of decision transparency.
questions.explanation: These are distinctly AI concerns. Training data may be misused (privacy). Biased data creates biased recommendations (bias). Can't explain why AI decided something (transparency).
questions.studyTip: Privacy + bias + transparency = the AI risk trio

questions.text: The only way to record project progress is to update the original Gantt chart.
questions.explanation: Multiple techniques work: annotating the original Gantt chart, creating a separate progress Gantt chart, maintaining a project log or journal. Know at least one method and how it enables tracking.
questions.studyTip: Options: annotate Gantt, separate progress chart, project log

questions.text: Project progress can be recorded through Gantt chart annotations, separate tracking charts, or project logs.
questions.explanation: Each method has merit. Annotations show planned vs actual on one chart. Separate charts keep the original clean. Logs capture details charts can't show. Explain HOW your choice enables tracking.
questions.studyTip: Name the method + explain how it shows progress

questions.text: For elderly audiences, the main design consideration is making text bigger.
questions.explanation: Large text is important, but complete answers address: large font for vision, high contrast, simple layout, limited text blocks, clear images. Also explain why alternatives (small text, complex graphs) are unsuitable.
questions.studyTip: Elderly: large text + high contrast + simple layout

questions.text: Designing for specific audiences requires considering their characteristics and explaining why alternatives are unsuitable.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses: 'Design A uses large font for elderly readers with vision difficulties. Design B's small text and dense paragraphs make it harder to read and interpret.'
questions.studyTip: State what works for them + what doesn't work + why

questions.text: Once you collect personal data, you can use it for any purpose as long as you protect it.
questions.explanation: The Privacy Act 1988 requires data only be used for the purpose it was collected. Using client data for unrelated purposes breaches the Act, even if the data is secure.
questions.studyTip: Collected for X? Only use for X. Different purpose = breach.

questions.text: Personal data can only be used or disclosed for the purpose for which it was collected.
questions.explanation: This is a key Australian Privacy Principle. Sending client data to third parties, using it for marketing when collected for service delivery—these breach the Act regardless of security measures.
questions.studyTip: Purpose limitation: collected for A, used only for A
